com.inqwell.any

Interface Transaction

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Any, Serializable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractTransaction, BasicTransaction, ClientTransaction, LocalTransaction, NullTransaction, PrimaryTransaction, RemoteTransaction, StackTransaction, TwoPhaseTransaction

    public interface Transaction
extends Any
    Define interface for representing transactions. The Transaction and Process interfaces are closely linked in that a transaction executes on behalf of a process.
    Version:
    $Revision: 1.7 $
    Author:
    $Author: sanderst $
    See Also:
    Any

    • Method Detail

      • start

        void start(Any root)
    throws AnyException
        Commence transaction semantics on the network of objects at the given root. Depending on the transaction implementation this may be a no-operation (optimistic) or a lock of all transaction-aware objects contained in the network (pessimistic) preventing join() or start() operations by blocking other transactions until the object is released.
        Throws:
        AnyException

      • join

        void join(Map m)
   throws AnyException
        Enters the given object into the list of objects managed by this transaction. Once a join operation for a given object has returned, the transaction has exclusive control over that object. Other transactions which attempt to join on the same object will be forced to wait until this transaction has completed or been aborted.
        Throws:
        AnyException

      • copyOnWrite

        void copyOnWrite(Map m)
          throws AnyException
        Sets up a copy of the given object which may subsequently be retrieved with getTransInstance(). By this means a client can mutate the private instance without affecting other simultaneously executing transactions.

        Although implementation specific, the object is generally also joined and therefore prevented from joining with other transactions.

        If copyOnWrite() has not been called then getTransInstance() returns the given object. This is acceptable for read operations and it is up to the client to ensure that copyOnWrite() is called prior to mutating the object.

        A pessimistic transaction would join all objects taking part on start() and therefore can be assured that both read and write operations take place exclusively. An optimistic implementation which does not lock any objects until they are mutated is content to read data which other transactions may be in the process of updating.

        Whether a particular transaction implementation calls join() when copyOnWrite() is called will depend on how that implementation wishes to arbitrate with other transactions operating on the same object. If join() is not called then the implementation must resolve any conflicts at commit time.

        Calling copyOnWrite() more than once is not an error and must not cause multiple instances to be created.

        Throws:
        AnyException

      • fieldChanging

        void fieldChanging(Map m,
                   Any f,
                   Any info)
        Allow the transaction the chance of noting which field(s) are being altered. The transaction may support fields information if it raises events on transactional objects

      • canCommit

        boolean canCommit()
           throws AnyException
        Determines whether the transaction can be committed or not. If all necessary join()s have executed then this method can return true. Otherwise the implementation has the opportunity to perform any arbitration of conflicts with other transactions.

        The canCommit() method need not be called by clients since the implementation of commit() should do so. canCommit() must complete before commit() semantics continue.

        Throws:
        AnyException

      • deleteIntent

        void deleteIntent(Map m)
           throws AnyException
        Indicates that this transaction will delete the given object when it is committed. Depending on implementation, the transaction may join() the given object.
        Throws:
        AnyException

      • createIntent

        void createIntent(Map m,
                  Any eventData)
           throws AnyException
        Indicates that this transaction will create the given object when it is committed.

        The caller may re-use the same Map object to create another object some time in the future (with a different unique key, of course)

        Throws:
        AnyException

      • resync

        void resync(Map keyVal,
            Map cachedObject,
            Map readObject)
     throws AnyException
        Resync any cached object with its externally stored (and therefore possibly externally changed) counterpart, whose unique key is given by keyVal. The cached object can be null (if the object is not in the cache) but the read object should not be.
        Throws:
        AnyException

      • commit

        void commit()
     throws AnyException
        Commits this transaction. The responsibilities of the commit() method are:
      • Update the public (Map) instances with any private copies created by copyOnWrite(). If the Map implementation in question implements the EventGenerator interface then an event can be generated to signal this occurrence to other observers of the object;
      • Manage any objects whose creation was prepared with createIntent(). If the Descriptor for the object implements the EventGenerator interface then an event can be generated to signal this occurrence to observers of the descriptor;
      • Remove any objects whose deletion was prepared with deleteIntent(). If the Map implementation in question implements the EventGenerator interface then an event can be generated to signal this occurrence to other observers of the object.
Throws:
AnyException

  • isAutoCommit

    boolean isAutoCommit()

  • interrupt

    void interrupt()
        throws AnyException
    Interrupt this transaction. This method may be called by threads other than the one executing the transaction context proper to signal that the transaction should be interrupted. Implementations will commonly set a flag which is periodically checked by the transaction's "owner" thread. This thread must throw a TransactionException when it detects interrupt.
    Throws:
    AnyException

  • isActive

    boolean isActive()
    Returns true if this transaction is in any way active. In general, a transaction is active if it has any instances pending creation, modification or deletion, or is managing any locks, but it can mean any state that the implementation deems other than idle.
    Returns:
    true if this transaction is active, false otherwise.

  • abort

    void abort()
    throws AnyException
    Discards any actions not already committed and reverts any actions which have.
    Throws:
    AnyException

  • setGatherEvents

    void setGatherEvents(boolean gather)
    Set whether this transaction gathers events it will raise (and those raised by automatic node-set pruning as a result) so that they can be retrieved within the context of an after-events action by calling getEventBundle()

  • getCreateList

    Map getCreateList(Descriptor d)
    Returns a list of instances that are currently within the transaction pending formal creation. If there are no such instances null is returned.
    Returns:
    A Map of unique key --> instance for those instances pending creation.

  • getModifyList

    Map getModifyList(Descriptor d)
    Returns a list of instances that are currently within the transaction pending modification. If there are no such instances null is returned.
    Returns:
    A Map of unique key --> instance for those instances pending modification.

  • getDeleteList

    Map getDeleteList(Descriptor d)
    Returns a list of instances that are currently within the transaction pending deletion. If there are no such instances null is returned.
    Returns:
    A Map of unique key --> instance for those instances pending deletion.

  • export

    void export(Map m,
            Transaction t)
     throws AnyException
    Attempt to export the given object from the specified transaction. to this. The exact operation of this method depends on the implementation of the two Transaction objects involved. Generally, if the given object is not taking part in this then this method does nothing. Otherwise the possibilities include remove from this and place in t or throw an exception if the object is already participating in t.
    Throws:
    AnyException

  • checkPrivilege

    void checkPrivilege(Any access,
                    Map node,
                    Any key)
    Check if the required privilege permits the requested access. The privilege information for the specified node is checked to see if the specified access is allowed for the process represented by this transaction.
    Throws:
    AnyRuntimeException - if the requested access is not allowed.

  • pushStackFrame

    Map pushStackFrame()
    Make a new stack frame and return the Map representing it. This same Map will be returned by subsequent calls to getCurrentStackFrame()

  • popStackFrame

    Map popStackFrame()
           throws StackUnderflowException
    Discard the current stack frame and return the Map representing the previous one. This same Map will be returned by subsequent calls to getCurrentStackFrame()
    Throws:
    StackUnderflowException

  • acquireResource

    Any acquireResource(Any spec,
                    ResourceAllocator allocator,
                    long timeout)
             throws AnyException
    Acquire the specified resource from the given allocator. The implementation may return the same resource more than once for a given specification and allocator during the lifetime of the transaction.

    If there are no resources available then the allocator determines the policy of either waiting or throwing. The timeout argument may be used by the allocator.

    The transaction implementation is responsible for releasing any resources this method returns on commit or abort.

    Parameters:
    spec -
    allocator -
    Returns:
    the resource
    Throws:
    AnyException

  • setIter

    Iter setIter(Iter i)
    Set the given iterator so that it can be used during the course of a transaction. This method allows an iterator to be passed within the transaction object so that things like Iter.remove() can be called at appropriate locations within a function network. The methods Transaction.commit() and Transaction.abort() may reset the current iterator to null.
    Returns:
    the existing iterator or null if none.

  • getIter

    Iter getIter()
    Get the current iterator.
    Returns:
    the existing iterator or null if none.
